Title: MEASLES - USA (75): (NORTH DAKOTA, ILLINOIS)
place_name: Williams County, North Dakota, United States
summary: Measles cases have been confirmed in North Dakota and Illinois. In North Dakota, the cases are in Williams County and are the first reemergence of measles since 2011. Health officials are advising residents to ensure they are up to date with their MMR vaccinations. In Illinois, cases have been confirmed in both southern Illinois and Cook County, with an outbreak declared in one area. Public health officials are emphasizing the importance of the MMR vaccine to prevent the spread of the disease.
full text:
[1] North Dakota (Williams County)
 
 Date: Mon 5 May 2025
 
 Source: North Dakota Monitor [edited]
 
 <https://northdakotamonitor.com/briefs/north-dakota-confirms-3-new-measles-cases-bringing-total-to-4/>
 
 
 
 
 
 North Dakota confirms 3 new measles cases, bringing total to 4
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------
 
 North Dakota now has 4 confirmed measles cases, the Department of Health and Human Services said Monday [5 May 2025]. All 4 cases are in Williams County in northwest North Dakota involving people who were not vaccinated, said Molly Howell, immunization director for the department.
 
 
 
 The department announced Friday [2 May 2025] the 1st confirmed case, a Williams County child who is believed to have contracted measles from an out-of-state visitor. The 3 additional cases are people who had contact with the child, Howell said. The cases are the first reemergence of measles in North Dakota since 2011, Howell said.
 
 
 
 A North Dakotan tested positive for measles in 2018, but after additional testing, the department confirmed that person did not have the illness, Howell said. "Our advice to anyone in North Dakota is to be up to date with your immunizations, especially the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine," Howell said. "Everyone starting at 12 to 15 months of age should receive their 1st dose of MMR vaccine and the 2nd dose is recommended at 4 to 6 years of age."
 
 
 
 Howell said infant vaccination rates in North Dakota are at about 81% and school-aged children have about a 90% rate, but those rates differ depending on location. She added there are no immediate plans to roll out mobile vaccination clinics because the vaccines are readily available at local health care providers. "It's more concerning in areas where there are lower vaccination rates, so ideally, we're hoping parents have a conversation with their trusted health care provider," she said. 
 
 
 
 With measles being a highly contagious illness, Howell said a 95% vaccination rate is recommended to contain the spread of the disease locally. Howell said North Dakota public health agencies did lose some COVID-19 pandemic-related funding from the federal government in recent weeks, but she doesn't believe the cuts will affect the state's ability to respond to the measles cases. "We'll continue to ensure that North Dakotans across the state have access to MMR vaccines, and other vaccines," she said.
 
 
 
 Howell said people should not downplay the seriousness of measles, but she did not want people to panic either. "What we want is for people to be informed of the benefits of vaccination versus the risks of the disease," she said. "We used to have 5000 to 6000 cases per year before the vaccine was available, but people died and were hospitalized. And now we have a way to prevent it and there's no reason for anyone to have to deal with this terrible disease." Howell said the department will continue to update its measles-dedicated website as more information becomes available.
 
 
 
 [Byline: Michael Achterling]

 The Illinois Department of Public Health reports the number of measles cases in the state is up to 6, including 4 in southern Illinois.
 
 
 
 According to the department, 2 new cases in southern Illinois were confirmed over the weekend, adding to 2 in the Marion area that were identified in April [2025].
 
 
 
 Two unrelated cases were previously confirmed in Cook County.
 
 
 
 According to IDPH, 1 of the new cases over the weekend is in the Franklin-Williamson Bi-County area. 
 
 
 
 They say this now meets the technical CDC definition of an "outbreak" in that area, which is when 3 or more cases are linked to one another. They say social links between the 3 cases are known.
 
 
 
 Another southern Illinois case may have visited locations in Missouri, including the St. Louis Aquarium.
 
 
 
 "The risk to the general public from measles remains low," IDPH Director Dr. Sameer Vohra said in a news release. "The key to preventing measles is the highly effective MMR vaccine. Two doses are 97% effective in preventing this serious infection. I recommend that our Illinois residents make sure they and their family members are up to date on the MMR vaccine and all other age-appropriate immunizations."

 "Well, there's a very easy blood test to determine your immune level, so if it's been since the early 1960s that you know that you have been vaccinated, it is good to go ahead and talk with your doctor and make sure that you are still fully immune. If not, you can get a booster from your local health department to put you back in immune status."

Ecuador registers 11 deaths from whooping cough so far in 2025, most of them are newborns
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Minister of Public Health, Edgar Lama, confirmed to PRIMICIAS on 5 May 2025 that Ecuador has registered 11 deaths due to pertussis (whooping cough) so far in 2025. Most of the deaths, he said, correspond to children under 5 years of age, with newborns being the most affected. During the interview, Lama explained that 321 cases of whooping cough have been officially reported as of the current epidemiological week. However, that figure has been reported since the previous week.

The most affected provinces are Guayas, Pichincha, ManabÃ­ and Santo Domingo, where vaccination brigades have already been deployed to contain the spread of this highly contagious disease. "Whooping cough is a bacterial disease that is spread by coughing and by the microparticles that remain in the air (...) Unfortunately, we have 11 deaths, of which 6 are under 5 years of age. Most of them are newborns." Edgar Lama, Minister of Health, pointed out that one of the main causes of the increase in cases is the decrease in compliance with the childhood vaccination schedule.

Although most parents comply with the first 3 doses of the pentavalent vaccine (at 2, 4 and 6 months), a worrying decrease in the application of boosters has been detected, which should be given at one and a half and 5 years of age. In view of the situation, the Ministry of Health has modified the vaccination schedule, bringing forward the doses to 2, 3 and 4 months, with the aim of offering earlier protection. In addition, vaccination of pregnant women has been intensified, so that babies are born with a certain degree of immunity.

The Minister also called on parents to send their children to classes wearing a mask, as a preventive measure, and recalled that schools will be key points to carry out mass vaccination in children. "One of the big problems that has caused whooping cough to grow in the country is because many parents have stopped vaccinating their children with boosters."

In a previous note published by this media, there had already been an alert about the sustained increase in cases of pertussis, which currently register 321 infections, while, in all of 2024, there were 141 reported cases. This coincides with a drop in childhood vaccination coverage, which barely exceeded 70% in some provinces, well below the 95% recommended by the WHO.

The Ministry of Health assured that it is keeping the epidemiological fences active and continues with information and vaccination campaigns, mainly in urban and school areas, with the aim of stopping the spread of this disease that, although preventable, can be lethal if not treated in time.

Title: MEASLES - USA (77): (NEW MEXICO, NEW YORK)
place_name: Curry County, New Mexico, United States
summary: Measles outbreaks have been reported in multiple counties across New Mexico and New York. Health officials are urging vigilance and vaccination to prevent further spread. The outbreaks have prompted increased awareness and action from school nurses and health departments, who are working to educate the public and address vaccine hesitancy. The virus is highly contagious and spreads through respiratory droplets.
full text:
[1] New Mexico (Curry & Lea counties)
 
 Date: Wed 7 May 2025
 
 Source: Source NM [edited]
 
 <https://sourcenm.com/briefs/new-mexico-health-department-reports-measles-spread-to-fifth-county/>
 
 
 
 
 
 New Mexico health department reports measles spread to 5th county
 
 -----------------------------------------------------------------
 
 New Mexico health officials on Wednesday [7 May 2025] reported the 1st measles case in Curry County, afflicting an infant, and warned of possible exposures last week at a social services office and Walmart. Additionally, 3 more measles cases emerged in Lea County, bringing New Mexico's case total to 71. Health officials have now diagnosed measles in 5 counties: Chaves, Curry, Do√±a Ana, Eddy and Lea.
 
 
 
 "Seeing measles in a new county underscores the need to remain vigilant and get vaccinated," NMDOH Chief Medical Officer Dr. Miranda Durham said in a statement. "It also serves as a reminder the measles outbreak in New Mexico isn't over. We urge New Mexicans to make sure their vaccination records are up to date."
 
 
 
 Between 1 Feb and 3 May 2025, 23 706 New Mexicans received a vaccine, nearly double the 2024 rate of 12 985 during the same time frame. Two doses of the vaccine can provide 97% protection against measles infection.
 
 
 
 Measles is a highly contagious respiratory virus spread through contact with droplets from an infected person talking, coughs or sneezes. Symptoms can take 1 to 3 weeks to appear, and people can spread measles before showing a fever, red eyes, cough, headache or the spotty red rash.
 
 
 
 Health officials said people at the following locations may be exposed to measles:
 
 
 
 30 Apr 2025, from 10:45 a.m. to 1:15 p.m., at the WIC Agency, 1216 Cameo St. in Clovis.
 
 30 Apr 2025, from 11:30 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. at Walmart, 3728 N. Prince Street in Clovis.
 
 4 May 2025, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at Firehouse Subs, 3734 N. Grimes Street., Suite. A in Hobbs.
 
 4 May 2025 from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m. at Bob's Thriftway, 904 Avenue D in Lovington.
 
 
 
 The current United States measles outbreak is the worst in 30 years, with cases reported in 30 of the 50 states and in Canada and Mexico. Across New Mexico, school nurses say they remain on alert for measles cases, while working to build trust with parents about vaccinations.
 
 
 
 After the outbreak first began in mid-February 2025, one of the first things Desiree Smith, a school nurse in Portales for the past 15 years, did was reach out to parents of unvaccinated children.
 
 
 
 "We wanted to let them know the process if their child was exposed, or has the measles," Smith said, noting that the latest guidance from NMDOH is for unvaccinated children to not attend school for 21 days from the last exposure. She said depending on the district, plans would need to be in place for remote learning during that period. We did have a couple of parents who had their children vaccinated after I explained the dangers of measles, obviously, the exposure time and time away from the classroom."
 
 
 
 School nurses in New Mexico are responsible for reviewing students' vaccine records, which are required by state law to be up to date. New Mexico, unlike other states, does not allow for "personal or philosophical exemptions," but does allow for religious or medical exemptions, which must be updated every year.
 
 
 
 Smith, who is also the director of the New Mexico School Nurse Association, said educational health providers are both potential first responders to an outbreak and play a crucial role in addressing the falling vaccine rates furthering spread.
 
 "Since COVID we have had we have seen a lot more vaccine hesitancy," Smith said.
 
 
 
 According to NMDOH data, New Mexico exemption rates are rising. Taos County has the highest exemption percentage at 3.35%, followed by De Baca County at 2.96% of students and Harding County in 3rd at 2.70%.
 
 
 
 Smith said she and other school nurses received guidance from the state health department in February [2025] to reach out to parents with exemptions, and alert them about the measles outbreak. Smith, who also sits on the board of the National Association of School Nurses, said the larger goal is to keep kids healthy enough for school.
 
 
 
 "As school nurses, we just want what is best for the children, we're trying to make sure they are safe, healthy and ready to learn and that time out of the classroom is minimized as much as possible," she said. "Vaccination is one of the best ways to do that."
 
 
 
 [Byline: Danielle Prokop]

 [Curry County is also on the eastern side of New Mexico but not adjacent to other counties with measles reports. No information is given about how the infant was infected. - Mod.LL]

 [2] New York (Orange County)
 
 Date: Thu 8 May 2025
 
 Source: Times Union [edited]
 
 <https://www.timesunion.com/health/article/measles-children-orange-county-new-york-20317372.php>
 
 
 
 
 
 Measles outbreak confirmed in Orange County
 
 -------------------------------------------
 
 Orange County health officials confirmed 3 measles cases in children under the age of 5, making New York the 12th state in the USA with a measles outbreak in 2025. An outbreak is defined as 3 or more related cases, according to the CDC. There was little information available about the Orange County cases. County officials declined to share specifics, such as the location of the cases or whether the children were vaccinated, citing patient privacy and health regulations.
 
 
 
 In a state Department of Health report released earlier in 2025, Orange County reported the lowest measles vaccination rate in the Capital Region and Mid-Hudson Region -- 64.9% as of 1 Jan 2025, well below the 95% rate needed to provide "herd immunity." A figure of 36.2% was reported in the 10950 zip code, which includes the town of Monroe and parts of Kiryas Joel.
 
 
 
 In March [2025], health officials confirmed the state's 1st measles case outside New York City in 2025 in an unvaccinated child from Nassau County.
 
 
 
 Measles is caused by a highly contagious virus that's airborne and spreads easily when an infected person breathes, sneezes or coughs. It is preventable through vaccines and has been considered eliminated from the USA since 2000. As the virus takes hold in USA communities with low vaccination rates, health experts fear that measles' spread could stretch on for a year.

Title: HEPATITIS A - BRAZIL: INCREASE IN CASES, MEN WHO HAVE SEX WITH MEN, VACCINATION EXPANSION
summary: Hepatitis A cases are on the rise in Brazil, particularly among adults, leading to an expansion of the vaccination program. The disease, traditionally more common in children, is now increasingly transmitted through sexual activity. The government is targeting specific groups for vaccination, including PrEP users, to reduce severe cases and complications. Prevention strategies include good hygiene practices, safe food handling, and safe sex practices.
full text:
Date: Tue 6 May 2025
 
 Source: Tribuna de Minas [in Portuguese, machine trans., edited]
 
 <https://tribunademinas.com.br/colunas/maistendencias/casos-de-hepatite-a-aumentam-no-brasil-e-riscos-sao-bem-perigosos/>
 
 
 
 
 
 Hepatitis A cases increase in Brazil and the risks are very dangerous
 
 -------------------
 
 Since 2023, Brazil has seen a significant increase in hepatitis A cases among adults, which led the Ministry of Health to expand the age range that can access the vaccine against the disease. Traditionally, hepatitis A was more common in children, especially those with poor access to basic sanitation services. However, the evolution of the epidemiological profile of the disease has brought a new concern: the increasing sexual transmission, particularly through anal sex, which has become one of the main forms of contagion. In 2023, approximately 69.5% of [Brazilian] hepatitis A cases were registered in adult men.
 
 
 
 Faced with the change in the hepatitis A profile, the federal government decided to expand vaccination against the disease. Since the beginning of May [2025], the vaccine has been recommended not only for children under 4 years old, but also for users of HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a medication that prevents HIV infection. This expansion aims to reduce the number of serious cases and associated complications, such as the need for liver transplants, which has already been observed in some cases.
 
 
 
 The government's goal is to vaccinate 80% of the 120 000 PrEP users in Brazil, with 2 doses administered 6 months apart. In addition, people with chronic liver disease, HIV, immunosuppressive conditions, and transplant recipients already had access to the vaccine free of charge. For other adults, the vaccine is available through the private health system.
 
 
 
 Hepatitis A is caused by a virus that is most often transmitted via the fecal-oral route, although unprotected sexual intercourse also poses a significant risk of infection. The disease may be asymptomatic or may present mild symptoms, such as fatigue, fever, nausea and yellow skin (jaundice). In most cases, the infection is self-limiting and disappears spontaneously within 6 months. However, in certain situations, it can develop into more serious forms, such as fulminant hepatitis, a rare condition that may require a liver transplant.
 
 
 
 Washing your hands frequently, cooking food thoroughly and disinfecting fruits and vegetables are basic and effective measures to prevent contagion. In addition, using condoms and paying attention to the origin of the water you drink, especially when traveling to regions with poor sanitation infrastructure, are fundamental strategies to reduce the risk of infection.
 
 
 
 [Byline: Yasmin Henrique]

Title: DIPHTHERIA - GERMANY
summary: Germany is experiencing a resurgence of diphtheria, prompting the national public health agency to issue an urgent vaccination warning. The disease, once largely eradicated, is spreading beyond initially vulnerable groups due to declining vaccination rates. The agency is recommending increased vaccination, enhanced surveillance, and improved diagnostics to combat the outbreak and prevent further spread. The situation underscores the importance of vaccination and public health vigilance.
full text:
Date: Fri 9 May 2025 16:45 IST
 
 Source: Jobaaj [abridged, edited]
 
 <https://stories.jobaaj.com/news-updates/world/germany-diphtheria-outbreak-rki-issues-urgent-vaccination-warning#google_vignette>
 
 
 
 
 
 Germany Diphtheria Outbreak: RKI Issues Urgent Vaccination Warning
 
 ---------
 
 Germany is facing a concerning resurgence of diphtheria, a dangerous infectious disease once thought to be largely eradicated. The Robert Koch Institute (RKI), Germany's national public health agency, has issued a warning about a potential nationwide outbreak, urging immediate action to prevent further spread. This alarming situation highlights the importance of vaccination and public health vigilance.
 
 
 
 The RKI's latest epidemiological bulletin reveals a significant increase in diphtheria cases, particularly those linked to the ST574 strain, first identified in Germany during a broader European outbreak in 2022. By April 2025, 126 cases were reported nationwide. This isn't just affecting one group; the RKI's report emphasizes that the disease is spreading beyond initially vulnerable populations like refugees and the homeless, affecting a wider segment of German society.
 
 
 
 The outbreak disproportionately impacts unvaccinated individuals, older adults with pre-existing conditions, drug users, and those experiencing homelessness. The widening reach of the disease signals a concerning change in transmission dynamics. The once-controlled diphtheria is now spreading more broadly within the German population.
 
 
 
 The [bacterium] _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, responsible for diphtheria, produces toxins that can cause severe respiratory issues, heart damage, and nerve problems -- potentially leading to death if left untreated. Symptoms, including fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing, can escalate rapidly.
 
 
 
 Historically, diphtheria was a devastating disease, claiming thousands of lives, especially children. The introduction of the diphtheria vaccine in 1913 dramatically reduced infection rates. However, recent years have witnessed a disturbing trend, with the RKI recording 51 confirmed cases in 2024 and 2 more by early 2025.
 
 
 
 This resurgence is largely attributed to declining vaccination rates. Only 64% of 15-month-old children in Germany are fully immunized against diphtheria. This lower-than-ideal rate contributes to the increased risk of outbreaks and severe cases of the disease.
 
 
 
 The RKI has issued several key recommendations to combat the outbreak:
 
 - Increased vaccination: The RKI strongly advocates for vaccination, particularly among at-risk populations. The standard vaccination schedule consists of three doses starting at 2 months of age, followed by booster shots.
 
 - Enhanced surveillance: Healthcare professionals are urged to conduct thorough testing for diphtheria, especially in suspected cases within vulnerable groups.
 
 - Improved diagnostics: Laboratories are advised to utilize PCR diagnostics to detect the diphtheria toxin gene and report any positive findings promptly.
 
 
 
 The RKI has identified 2 genetically linked sub-clusters of cases, one near Frankfurt and another in Berlin, with possible links to neighboring countries, indicating potential cross-border spread. The institute continues to closely monitor the situation.
 
 
 
 The diphtheria outbreak in Germany serves as a stark reminder of the importance of vaccination and ongoing public health vigilance. The RKI's urgent warnings highlight the need for increased vaccination rates, improved surveillance, and prompt medical attention for anyone experiencing potential symptoms. This collective effort is crucial to preventing a wider spread and protecting public health from this potentially fatal disease. Staying informed and ensuring your vaccinations are up to date are vital steps in mitigating the risk.

Title: DIPHTHERIA - CHAD: (BATHA, BARH EL GAZAL) SPREAD, ALERT
summary: Health authorities are working to contain a diphtheria outbreak in the Batha and Barh El Gazal regions. The Ministry of Public Health, with partners, is implementing strategies to address the crisis. These strategies include training healthcare workers, establishing treatment protocols, and strengthening epidemiological surveillance. Community engagement through awareness campaigns and vaccination programs are also key. The outbreak impacts the health system, necessitating collaboration among stakeholders.  <https://tchadvision.com/urgence-sanitaire-renforcement-des-efforts-contre-la-diphterie-dans-le-batha-et-le-barh-el-gazal-informations-cruciales-a-ne-pas-manquer/>
 
 
 
 
 
 The rapid spread of the diphtheria outbreak in the Batha and Barh El Gazal regions has prompted an unprecedented mobilization of health authorities.
 
 
 
 Faced with this potentially fatal disease, the Ministry of Public Health, in collaboration with various partners, is implementing effective strategies to contain the crisis. According to the latest statistics, several cases have been reported in recent weeks, urging medical teams to intensify their efforts.
 
 
 
 A Coordinated Response to the Epidemic
 
 --------------------------------------
 
 Strengthening Knowledge on Diphtheria:
 
 
 
 The first crucial step in combating this outbreak is to enhance the knowledge of key actors across the healthcare chain. Training and information exchange sessions are regularly organized, involving district health officials and community health workers. The aim is to ensure a deep understanding of the symptoms, transmission modes, and preventive measures.
 
 
 
 Case Management Protocols and Epidemiological Surveillance:
 
 
 
 Establishing clear protocols for the treatment of diphtheria cases is also a top priority. Medical teams are provided with specific guidelines that facilitate early diagnosis and appropriate care. Simultaneously, strengthened epidemiological surveillance enables the rapid identification of new cases, ensuring a swift and coordinated response.
 
 
 
 Community Engagement: Advocacy and Awareness:
 
 
 
 The involvement of local opinion leaders plays a key role in raising public awareness. Advocacy meetings are held to encourage these influential figures to inform citizens about preventive measures and the symptoms of diphtheria. This collaborative approach fosters greater community adherence to public health efforts.
 
 
 
 Vaccination: An Essential Tool:
 
 
 
 Vaccination remains one of the most effective ways to control the spread of diphtheria. Intensified immunization campaigns are being rolled out across many villages, focusing particularly on children, who are the most vulnerable. The goal is to achieve a high vaccination coverage rate to prevent any resurgence of the disease.
 
 
 
 Implications for Local and Regional Public Health
 
 -------------------------------------------------
 
 Impact on the Health System:
 
 
 
 Managing this outbreak has significant repercussions on the health system at various levels. Such a crisis can lead to additional costs in terms of care, treatment, and hospitalization. Enhancing the response capacity of healthcare infrastructure has therefore become a pressing priority.
 
 
 
 Collaboration Among Health Stakeholders:
 
 
 
 Fighting diphtheria requires close cooperation between all involved stakeholders. Ongoing communication between the Ministry of Health, non-governmental organizations, and local communities is essential to optimize resources and strengthen awareness efforts.
 
 
 
 Conclusion: What Are the Prospects for the Future?:
 
 
 
 As efforts intensify to fight diphtheria in the Batha and Barh El Gazal regions, it is crucial to maintain a sustained commitment to public health. Current initiatives demonstrate the determination of all stakeholders to bring the outbreak under control and protect vulnerable populations.
 
 
 
 In the short term, tangible results are expected, including a reduction in the number of cases and improved knowledge within communities. In the long term, this crisis could serve as an opportunity to strengthen and sustain local health systems, thereby improving preparedness for future health threats. The coming months will be critical, and continued vigilance will be essential to stay on track and prevent a resurgence of diphtheria.

summary: Since the beginning of 2025, a province in the Democratic Republic of Congo has been experiencing a measles outbreak. The Provincial Health Division is urging parents to vaccinate their children, as measles can cause serious complications. Awareness campaigns and a vaccination drive are underway to combat the spread of the disease. Medical treatment is available free of charge.
full text:
Date: Sat 16 Aug 2025
Source: Agence Congolaise de Presse [in French, machine trans., edited]
<https://acp.cd/sante/sud-kivu-187-deces-et-plus-de-4-400-cas-de-rougeole-enregistres-depuis-janvier-2025/>


South Kivu: 187 deaths and more than 4400 cases of measles recorded since January 2025
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
One hundred eighty-seven (187) deaths and 4400 confirmed measles cases have been recorded since January 2025 in South Kivu Province, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, ACP learned Saturday [16 Aug 2025] from statistics provided by the provincial health division.

According to figures from the Provincial Health Division (DPS), "187 deaths and 4498 measles cases have been registered since the beginning of 2025. Of the 34 health zones in the province, 30 are already affected. Kalole health zone is the most impacted, with 833 cases reported since January [2025], followed by Kitutu (702 cases) and Nyangezi (660 cases). In the city of Bukavu, Ibanda commune has already recorded 67 cases, but no deaths," the document states.

The situation remains concerning: in the past week, 204 cases and 5 deaths were reported, compared to 230 cases and 10 deaths the previous week. A highly contagious viral disease, measles can cause severe complications and even death. The Provincial Health Division (DPS) is therefore urging parents to ensure that their children receive the 2 recommended vaccine doses: the 1st at 9 months and the 2nd at 15 months.

"Some parents do not take their children to the hospital out of ignorance. If a child is under 24 months and has not received both doses, they can still be vaccinated. Signs of measles include red eyes, tearing, and small skin rashes on the body," recalled the communications officer of DPS/South Kivu.

To curb the spread of the epidemic, the DPS, with support from its partners -- including UNICEF, WHO, and the Congolese government -- is currently carrying out awareness campaigns and preparing a vaccination drive in 6 health zones. Medical treatment for measles is free of charge in all state health facilities.

Health authorities are urging the population, especially parents, to vaccinate all children to break the chain of transmission of this life-threatening disease for young children.

full text:
Date: Sun 11 May 2025
 
 Source: RNZ [edited]
 
 <https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/national/560630/new-measles-case-in-auckland-alerts-issued-over-ferries-and-supermarket>
 
 
 
 
 
 New measles case in Auckland -- alerts issued over ferries and supermarket
 
 ---------------------------------------------
 
 The person at the centre of a new measles alert in Auckland is a crew member on a Fullers360 ferry, the company has confirmed.
 
 
 
 Alerts have been issued after a new measles case was confirmed today [11 May 2025], with people in Auckland asked to check if they could have been exposed. Health New Zealand said the case was linked to overseas travel, and the person with measles had been at Woolworths Kelston, on Fullers360 ferries, and at an Auckland carpark during the time they could be infectious.
 
 
 
 It was thought the person contracted measles while in Asia; however, at the point they flew back to New Zealand, they had not yet progressed to the infectious stage of the disease, Health NZ said. Both the person with measles and their household were being supported, and some were now in quarantine to help reduce the chance of the disease spreading.
 
 
 
 Fullers360 has confirmed in a statement that it was a crew member. "Staff who are considered to have been in possible contact with the known case in our crew are being contacted by Health New Zealand and will be guided by them on any further necessary steps."
 
 
 
 Auckland Transport (AT) spokesperson Blake Crayton-Brown said AT was notified by Fullers early on Sunday [11 May 2025] evening. He said it was unlikely that sailings will be affected on Monday [12 May 2025].
 
 
 
 Crayton-Brown said the Downtown Carpark on Customs Street -- which has also been identified as a location of interest -- is managed by AT. He said they would be talking to staff on Monday [12 May 2025] to identify any staff who may have been exposed. Crayton-Brown said they would also be speaking to HNZ to confirm which parts of the carpark were considered exposure locations on Monday 5 May, as there are several different locations for stairs and lifts in the building. He said AT will be communicating to staff this week about the importance of being vaccinated for measles.
 
 
 
 Measles, one of the most contagious diseases known, can be fatal or cause serious long-term health consequences, particularly for young children. The virus can live in the air long after the infectious person has left. About 10 percent of people who contract it get so sick they need hospital treatment, experts have previously said, and about 90 percent of those who come into contact with it and are not immune are likely to be infected.
 
 
 
 New Zealand's general immunization rates -- and community "herd protection" -- have been dropping since the COVID-19 pandemic, with experts recently issuing stark warnings to vaccinate children, as an epidemic could be one plane ride away.
 
 
 
 People who were at [the following] Auckland locations during [certain] times are being asked to check their immunisation status and stay vigilant for symptoms (see below). Title: HEPATITIS A - CZECH REPUBLIC: INCREASED CASES AND FATALITIES
summary: Hepatitis A infections are rapidly increasing in the Czech Republic. The virus, which causes liver inflammation, spreads through contact with contaminated sources and thrives in areas with poor sanitation. While many infected individuals show no symptoms, some experience serious health problems. The disease is affecting various age groups, with higher risks for older adults and those with existing liver conditions. Health officials are promoting vaccination, particularly among vulnerable populations, but controlling the spread is challenging due to difficulties in contact tracing and adherence to preventative measures.
full text:
Date: Tue 13 May 2025 09:14 CEST
 
 Source: Euronews [abridged, edited]
 
 <https://tinyurl.com/47n78f2u>
 
 
 
 
 
 Hepatitis A is spreading rapidly in the Czech Republic with 6 deaths so far
 
 -------------------------------------------
 
 The Czech Republic is seeing a surge of hepatitis A infections that does not appear to be slowing down. The country recorded 450 cases and 6 deaths from hepatitis A in the first 4 months of 2025, compared with 636 cases and 2 deaths all of 2024.
 
 
 
 But Czech health officials said the actual number of infections is likely much higher because of how difficult it is to track the spread of the virus, which causes liver inflammation that can be fatal in rare cases. "We know from experience that even one confirmed case can subsequently mean a big problem," the State Health Institute (SZ√ö) said in a statement.
 
 
 
 People can be infected after contact with a sick person's stool, for example, via unwashed hands, contaminated food or water, or dirty door handles. Places with poor sanitation and hygiene are the ideal breeding ground for the virus.
 
 
 
 Many infected people do not have symptoms, but about 10% experience serious health problems that can lead to liver failure and death, Czech officials said. Adults aged 50 and older and people who already have chronic liver disease are at higher risk of complications.
 
 
 
 The capital city, Prague, and the surrounding Central Bohemian region, as well as the Moravia-Silesian region bordering Poland and Slovakia, have reported the most hepatitis A cases in 2025. The virus is spreading among children, teenagers, young adults, and people engaged in "risky behavior," officials said. In Prague, for example, nearly 1 in 3 patients are homeless, and many use drugs.
 
 
 
 Health officials encouraged people to get vaccinated against hepatitis A. Two doses taken 6 to 18 months apart can help protect people against infection. Because many infected people are homeless, Czech health workers have distributed the vaccine to shelters for free. People who work closely with drug users and those living on the streets are also being vaccinated in Prague.
 
 
 
 But "it is very difficult for these people to comply with anti-epidemic measures, and contact tracing is especially problematic," making it harder to control the spread of the virus, officials said. In 2024, officials tracked down 6375 contacts of people infected with hepatitis A.
 
 
 
 [Byline: Gabriela Galvin]

 Belize Health Ministry confirms measles outbreak; urges public to get vaccinated
 
 -------------------------------
 
 The Ministry of Health and Wellness (MOHW) has issued a public health update confirming a measles outbreak in Belize, with 2 lab-confirmed cases and 5 additional clinically diagnosed cases, all linked to one of the initial patients. The ministry has intensified surveillance in the Spanish Lookout area, where suspected cases are under investigation. The cases are believed to be linked to recent travel from Chihuahua, Mexico.
 
 
 
 MOHW is urging individuals who are not vaccinated to avoid traveling to Spanish Lookout. Officials stress that while investigations are ongoing, the full scope of the outbreak is not yet known. The ministry has pledged to keep the public informed as new information becomes available.

Unvaccinated individuals over 18 months should get 2 doses a month apart. A booster dose is recommended for anyone who only received one dose, and those unsure of their vaccination status should get one dose as a precaution.
 
 
 
 [Non-immune] travelers 12 months and older should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks before travel. Unvaccinated children under 1 year should consult a healthcare provider.
 
 
 
 The public is advised to act swiftly after potential exposure by getting vaccinated within 3 days and contacting a healthcare provider. MOHW emphasized that while the MMR vaccine is safe and effective, it is not recommended for pregnant individuals, people with severe allergies to previous MMR doses, or those who are immunocompromised.
 
 
 
 The ministry also outlined quarantine measures following exposure: no quarantine for vaccinated individuals, 21 days for unvaccinated individuals, and 14 days for those vaccinated after exposure.

Title: MEASLES - USA (81): EXPERT VACCINATION COMMENTARY
place_name: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
summary: A measles outbreak in the Great Plains region of the USA raises concerns about the potential loss of the country's measles elimination status. The outbreak is linked to declining MMR vaccine immunizations due to nonmedical exemptions. To address the outbreak, health officials have modified MMR vaccination recommendations, including earlier doses for infants and a second dose for adults in affected areas. These changes are similar to those used in countries with widespread measles. The article emphasizes the need for healthcare providers to be prepared for similar outbreaks and the potential need to revise MMR immunization practices.
full text:
Date: Tue 6 May 2025
 
 Source: Annals of Internal Medicine [edited]
 
 <https://tinyurl.com/bdz8s4ws>
 
 
 
 
 
 Citation: Hotez PJ. Measles, Mumps, Rubella Immunization and the Resurgence of Measles in America. Ann Intern Med. 2025 <https://doi.org/10.7326/ANNALS-25-01730>
 
 
 
 As a very large and deadly measles epidemic spreads across 4 states in the Great Plains region of the USA, there are concerns that transmission of the measles virus will continue for months. The USA might even lose its measles elimination status if virus transmission persists for 12 months or longer (1). Ironically, this criterion was established by the CDC after the USA first achieved this hard-fought goal in 2000.
 
 
 
 The 2025 USA Great Plains measles epidemic emerged after declines in measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine immunizations in West Texas and adjoining areas, where nonmedical vaccine exemptions for philosophical or religious reasons have steadily increased (2). Almost a decade ago, future measles epidemics were predicted for West Texas and the Texas Panhandle, where this current one began (3). Now, the only way it can be slowed or halted is through catch-up MMR immunization and public relations campaigns.
 
 
 
 If regular measles epidemics become a new normal or if the USA does lose its elimination status, both pediatricians and internal medicine physicians may need to revise some aspects of their MMR immunizations practices. Currently, the CDC and its Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommend that children receive their first MMR dose (or MMRV, adding a varicella vaccine) at 12 to 15 months of age, followed by a second dose at 4 to 6 years of age. However, in April 2025, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) modified these recommendations for 10 Texas counties where measles transmission is occurring (4). For young children, these recommendations are similar to those proposed by the WHO in countries where measles cases are widespread (5).
 
 
 
 The changes recommended for West Texas are instructive for both pediatricians and internal medicine physicians who might soon face similar measles epidemics in several areas in the USA.
 
 
 
 The first modification for areas of ongoing measles transmission includes children aged 6 to 11 months receiving an "outbreak" or early MMR dose. This change is based on the recognition that maternal antibodies to measles may wane significantly over this period, leaving the infant highly vulnerable to measles infection. Should an infant receive their first dose between 6 and 9 months of age, the WHO recommends that this immunization should be recorded as a "supplemental dose" before infants receive 2 additional MMR doses according to the usual schedule (5). In the USA, the CDC recommends a 3-dose measles schedule for any infant who receives their first MMR dose at 6 to 11 months, with the last 2 doses the same as recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (6). Three doses may be required because the immune response to MMR before one year of age is not as robust as it is for older children (5). For this current outbreak, the Texas DSHS also recommends that children aged 12 months and older who have already received their first dose of MMR vaccine receive their follow-up dose after 28 days, in other words sooner than 4 to 6 years of age (5).
 
 
 
 At the opposite end of the age spectrum, both the Texas DSHS and CDC do not recommend the MMR vaccine for any adult born before 1957. This assumes that measles transmission was practically ubiquitous in the first half of the 20th century, and virus infection elicits enduring immunity. However, the CDC makes an important exception for health-care personnel who are "serving a measles outbreak area" or work in a health-care facility where there is a measles outbreak. For such health-care workers, 2 MMR doses are recommended "regardless of birth year, who lack other presumptive evidence of measles immunity," meaning laboratory evidence of immunity or documentation of immunization (6).
 
 
 
 Conversely, the recommendation for administering a second MMR dose in childhood was adopted in 1989, and those born after that time do not require an additional vaccine dose. There are no criteria, even during an outbreak, for administering a third dose of MMR.
 
 
 
 What about all other adults? In the absence of a measles epidemic, the CDC does not recommend revaccinating adults born between 1957 and 1989. One dose of MMR vaccine is considered adequate for most adults, and after vaccination "there is no recommendation for a catch-up program among adults for a second dose of MMR" (6). Also, providers do not generally require screening patients for evidence of immunity.
 
 
 
 However, during measles epidemics (or presumably if measles returns widely across the USA), the CDC notes that "health departments may provide additional recommendations to protect their communities, including a second dose" for adults. Along those lines, the Texas DSHS recently recommended for adults living in the 10 affected counties that those born after 1957 (and received one MMR vaccine from that time) receive a second dose (4). If measles returns widely across the USA, this could become a new standard recommendation. The rationale: Although a single dose of MMR vaccine is still considered to give lifelong protection against measles, its effectiveness (93%) is less than 2 doses (97%). In addition, a small percentage of adults who were children during a period from 1963 to 1967 may have received an inactivated measles vaccine that has since been withdrawn -- those individuals should receive 2 MMR doses spaced 28 days apart (6).
 
 
 
 Because the MMR vaccine contains live virus strains, it is contraindicated for pregnant women or those with severe immunodeficiency. However, the MMR vaccine can be given to HIV-infected children and adults who do not have evidence of severe immunosuppression, which the CDC defines on the basis of CD4 counts and percentages (6). The American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy has also issued guidelines for MMR immunizations after immunosuppressive therapies for cancer and hematopoietic cell transplantations (7).
 
 
 
 Regarding international travel, currently no country requires documentation of measles vaccination or immune status for entry. However, given the increase of measles both in the USA and abroad, the CDC recommends that children receive 2 MMR vaccine doses, or that infants aged 6 through 11 months receive their first dose of MMR vaccine, followed by 2 additional doses according to the routine schedule (6). Adults should also receive 2 doses of MMR or measles-containing vaccine unless they have presumptive evidence of immunity.
 
 
 
 Given the increase in antivaccine sentiments in Texas and the Great Plains, and increasingly across the United States (8), we may need to prepare for the possibility that our nation's measles elimination status could be lost. The current situation in West Texas and adjoining states could soon be replicated elsewhere.
 
 
 
 References
 
 ----------
 
 1. Papania MJ, Orenstein WA. Defining and assessing measles elimination goals. J Infect Dis. 2004;189(Suppl 1):S23-S26. <https://doi.org/10.1086/381556>
 
 2. Olive JK, Hotez PJ, Damania A, et al. The state of the antivaccine movement in the United States: a focused examination of nonmedical exemptions in states and counties. PLoS Med. 2018;15(6):e1002578. <https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1002578>
 
 3. Hotez PJ. Texas and its measles epidemics. PLoS Med. 2016;13(10):e1002153. <https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1002153>
 
 4. Shetty V. PHFPC Briefing. Texas 2025 measles outbreak. Accessed at <www.dshs.texas.gov/sites/default/files/phfpcommittee/docs/Measles-Briefing-PHFPC-04.09.2025.pdf> on 12 Apr 2025.
 
 5. World Health Organization: Measles vaccines: WHO position paper - April 2017. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2017;92(17):205-227. <https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28459148/>
 
 6. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Routine measles, mumps, and rubella vaccination. Accessed at <www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/mmr/hcp/recommendations.html>on 12 Apr 2025.
 
 7. Pergam SA, Englund JA, Kamboj M, et al. Preventing measles in immunosuppressed cancer and hematopoietic cell transplantation patients: a position statement by the American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant. 2019;25(11):e321-e330. <https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bbmt.2019.07.034>
 
 8. Hotez P. It won't end with COVID: countering the next phase of American antivaccine activism 2025-29. PLOS Glob Public Health. 2025;5(1):e0004020. <https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgph.0004020>

Title: MEASLES - PERU: ex USA
summary: A recent case of measles in a child who traveled to the USA has prompted health authorities to issue an epidemiological alert. The Ministry of Health has implemented measures including increased surveillance in healthcare facilities and vaccination campaigns. The public is reminded that the measles vaccine is free and available. Health officials are emphasizing the importance of vaccination and are working to prevent further spread of the virus.
full text:
Date: Tue 13 May 2025
 
 Source: El Comercio [in Spanish, machine trans., edited] 
 
 <https://elcomercio.pe/lima/alerta-por-sarampion-en-peru-minsa-informa-a-el-comercio-sintomas-medidas-de-prevencion-y-el-peligro-del-movimiento-antivacunas-noticia/>
 
 
 
 
 
 Measles in Peru -- Child returns infected from the USA, and epidemiological cordon is activated
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 A new case of measles in a child has raised alarms in the country's health system. The Ministry of Health (Minsa) confirmed that an 11-year-old boy, who had recently traveled to the USA -- a country facing active outbreaks of the disease in several cities -- tested positive for measles. Because this was an imported case, authorities issued an epidemiological alert to all health centers in the country due to the risk of reintroduction of the virus into the country.
 
 
 
 According to the Ministry of Health (MINSA), the diagnosis was made after a relative of the child was confirmed to have measles in the USA. The child is receiving medical care, and an epidemiological cordon has been activated to monitor all contacts. While no new suspected cases have been detected so far, the Ministry has strengthened surveillance in hospitals, health centers, and private clinics as a preventive measure.
 
 
 
 The Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) warns that measles is easily transmitted through the air, through droplets expelled by an infected person when coughing or sneezing. As part of the immediate response, everyone close to an infected child is being vaccinated, and immunization campaigns have been intensified in various regions. The public is reminded that the measles vaccine is free and available at all public health centers.
 
 
 
 In addition to strengthening epidemiological surveillance, the Ministry of Health (MINSA) has mobilized its network of public and private health centers to respond to any potential outbreak. At the same time, information campaigns are being launched for parents to emphasize the importance of completing their children's vaccination schedules.
 
 
 
 PAHO has reiterated that measles eradication will only be possible if vaccination coverage is maintained at or above 95%, with the administration of 2 doses. It also recommends strengthening health surveillance systems to promptly detect any suspected cases, especially those with a history of travel abroad. If new infections are confirmed, PAHO emphasizes the need to act quickly through targeted vaccination campaigns and actively searching for potentially infected individuals to prevent further spread of the virus.
 
 
 
 In an interview with El Comercio, Dr. C√©sar Munayco, director general of the National Center for Epidemiology, Prevention, and Disease Control of the Ministry of Health (Minsa), explained that the affected child is 11 years old and that, during a trip to Nebraska, United States, he had contact with a cousin. Upon returning to Peru, he was informed that this relative had been diagnosed with measles.
 
 
 
 "The United States is experiencing a serious epidemic, as are Mexico, Canada, and several European countries, which increases the risk of imported cases. The minor has already been discharged, and we are currently coordinating with different centers to monitor possible cases that may come from abroad," he noted.
 
 
 
 Regarding the epidemiological cordon, the specialist indicated that it is a strategy to prevent the spread of new cases. "Once a case is identified, rigorous monitoring is carried out. So far, no other associated cases have been found. Basically, an area of up to five 5 blocks around the patient's home is blocked off, and people in the surrounding area are checked for symptoms. Although no additional cases have yet been identified, monitoring will continue for several days," he added.
 
 
 
 Dr. Munayco emphasized that the most important preventive measure is vaccination, especially for children traveling abroad. "Anyone who develops a fever followed by a rash should immediately go to the nearest health center for evaluation. Unfortunately, in recent years, vaccination schedule adherence has been affected because some families are reluctant to get vaccinated. It is essential to adhere to the free schedule to protect lives," he emphasized.
 
 
 
 For her part, Dr. Virginia Garaycochea Cannon, vice dean of the Peruvian Medical Association and a pediatrician, noted that symptoms that should be addressed include nasal congestion, red eyes, sore throat, persistent dry cough, and high fever.
 
 
 
 "Later, a rash appears on different parts of the body. Epidemiological fencing is essential; it involves identifying the source of infection, isolating it, and determining who has been in contact with the patient. These contacts are vaccinated or kept under strict surveillance. It is meticulous work, very similar to that of health intelligence," she explained.
 
 
 
 Dr. Garaycochea recommended that anyone with compatible symptoms immediately isolate themselves and seek medical attention without exposing others along the way. "If the doctor detects a high level of suspicion, they may ask the patient to open their mouth to identify the so-called 'Koplik spot,' a characteristic sign of measles, and thus activate the isolation protocol," she commented.
 
 
 
 Regarding the impact of the anti-vaccine movement, the specialist recalled that it originated in a fraudulent study linking vaccines to autism, a connection that was denied and discredited by the scientific community. "Measles is not a mild disease. It can be very serious and has no specific treatment. That's why it's crucial for the population to understand that the best way to protect themselves is to complete their vaccination schedule," she concluded.
 
 
 
 [Byline: Sebasti√°n Ram√≠rez Mendoza]

 2 new measles cases confirmed in Cass County; 1 hospitalized
 
 ------------------------------------------------------------
 
 Two new measles cases were confirmed in Cass County on Sunday [11 May 2025], bringing North Dakota's total cases to 11 since 2 May 2025, according to the state Department of Health and Human Services. The department reported both people were unvaccinated and 1 was hospitalized as a result of the disease. Both people are believed to have contracted measles from international travel.
 
 
 
 Two Essentia Health clinics in the Fargo area were exposed to the disease and public health officials said unvaccinated individuals present at those facilities should quarantine themselves for 21 days to monitor for symptoms. The 2 clinics exposed were:
 
 
 
 - Essentia Health - The Lights West Fargo Clinic from 2:30 to 6 p.m., 7 May 2025. The entrance to the clinic is shared with Bar Down Sports Bar and Restaurant.
 
 - Essentia Health Walk-in Care Clinic from 5:30 to 8 p.m., 9 May 2025.
 
 
 
 Last week, public health officials reported 3 schools in Williston were exposed to measles that resulted in about 150 unvaccinated students isolating at home to monitor for symptoms. Nine measles cases have been confirmed in Williams County since 2 May 2025.
 
 
 
 The health department recommends children between 12-15 months old should receive their 1st dose of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine and a 2nd dose between 4-6 years of age. 
 
 
 
 "People who are vaccinated and exposed to measles are not likely to develop the disease," said Molly Howell, immunization director for HHS. "MMR vaccination is critical to preventing the spread of measles in the community. Anyone who is eligible and has not yet been vaccinated is encouraged to contact a trusted health care provider about MMR vaccination."
 
 
 
 Howell said the MMR vaccine is 93% effective after one dose and 97% effective after a 2nd dose. Adults born before 1957 are generally presumed immune due to natural exposure, the department said.
 
 
 
 Immunization records for North Dakota residents can be reviewed through the HHS website or by contacting a health care provider.
 
 
 
 [Byline: Michael Achterling]

 Cuyahoga County reports 1st confirmed measles case in 2025
 
 ----------------------------------------------------------
 
 Cuyahoga County has confirmed its 1st case of measles in 2025, in an unvaccinated child. The child was previously treated at the Cleveland Clinic's Hillcrest Hospital in Mayfield Heights, and sent home to isolate until it ran its course, according to a Thursday [8 May 2025] news release from the Cuyahoga County Board of Health.
 
 
 
 County health officials are now warning people who were in the hospital's atrium lobby between 3:50 p.m. and 6:15 p.m. on Friday, 2 May 2025, that they may have been exposed. Hospital workers are now working with county health officials to notify people who are known to have been exposed.
 
 
 
 The child visited the hospital for lab work on Friday, 2 May 2025, according to the release. The child returned on Sunday, 4 May 2025, for emergency treatment, when medical officials suspected the child may have measles. The illness was first reported on Sunday, 4 May 2025, then confirmed to the Cuyahoga County Board of Health on Tuesday, 6 May 2025, according to the release.
 
 
 
 Anyone who was in the Hillcrest Hospital atrium lobby during that time who does not have evidence of immunity to measles is urged to quarantine at home, staying away from work, school or public places for at least 21 days.
 
 
 
 In Northeast Ohio, Ashtabula, Holmes and Knox counties have reported confirmed measles cases this year [2025]. Ohio reported 90 cases of measles in 2022, including 85 cases related to an outbreak in Central Ohio, according to the release. There was 1 case in 2023 and 7 in 2024.

 <https://www.kwch.com/2025/05/10/kdhe-reports-positive-measles-case-reno-county/>
 
 
 
 
 
 KDHE reports positive measles case in Reno County
 
 -------------------------------------------------
 
 Health officials have confirmed a positive case of measles found in a person living in Reno County. According to the Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE), the case is not associated with any of the USA measles outbreaks and does not represent community transmission in Reno County.  Israel: 5 children hospitalized in ICU with measles
 
 ----------------------------------------
 
 The Israeli Health Ministry announced on Thursday [15 May 2025] that 5 unvaccinated children have been in intensive care after contracting measles, as part of a growing global resurgence of the disease. Three of the children remain in critical care units, according to the statement. In response, Israeli health authorities have launched an emergency vaccination campaign targeting both children and adults in areas with low immunization rates.

Title: MEASLES - SOMALIA: (SOMALILAND) 220 CONFIRMED CASES
summary: A measles outbreak is rapidly spreading across Somaliland, prompting health officials to call for increased vaccination efforts and public health surveillance. The outbreak is affecting multiple regions, with a significant number of cases reported. The disease, which primarily impacts children, is causing concern due to its potential to strain the healthcare system. Health authorities are urging parents to seek medical care and ensure children receive vaccinations. The outbreak adds to existing health challenges in the region, and officials warn that the situation could worsen without intervention.
full text:
Date: Thu 15 May 2025
 
 Source: Hiiraan Online [edited]
 
 <https://www.hiiraan.com/news4/2025/May/201517/somaliland_grapples_with_measles_outbreak_as_cases_surge_past_200.aspx?utm_source=hiiraan&utm_medium=SomaliNewsUpdateFront>
 
 
 
 
 
 A fast-spreading measles outbreak is sweeping across Somaliland, with more than 220 confirmed cases prompting urgent calls for vaccination and heightened public health surveillance.
 
 
 
 The Ministry of Health Development said Thursday [15 May 2025] that 227 cases have been recorded across 6 regions, with the majority in Hargeisa and Berbera. Health authorities have raised concerns over the virus's rapid transmission, especially among children, many of whom are now being treated in hospitals.
 
 
 
 "This is a nationwide outbreak, and measles is a serious illness," said Dr. Ahmed Mahmoud Jama, director general of the ministry. "It primarily affects children, but the consequences go far beyond the individual. The disease threatens to disrupt our healthcare system and economy."
 
 
 
 According to health officials, 30 suspected cases were tested before the outbreak was declared -- 26 were confirmed positive. Hospitals in Hargeisa are managing a surge in cases, with some patients in critical condition, though no fatalities have been officially confirmed.
 
 The regional case breakdown is as follows:
 
 
 
 - Hargeisa: 160
 
 - Berbera: 27
 
 - Burao: 14
 
 - Sheikh: 5
 
 - Aynaba: 4
 
 - Smaller clusters: Baligubadle, Erigavo, Gabiley
 
 
 
 Measles is a viral illness spread through coughing, sneezing, and close contact. Symptoms include high fever, persistent cough, runny nose, and red rashes that appear on the skin. The disease is preventable through vaccination, but inconsistent coverage and limited access to health services have left many children in the region vulnerable.
 
 
 
 The outbreak adds to a growing list of health challenges in the region. In recent years, dengue fever -- a mosquito-borne illness not previously common in Somaliland -- has also emerged, leading to several deaths and straining already fragile health infrastructure.
 
 
 
 Health authorities urge parents to seek medical care at the 1st sign of symptoms and to ensure their children receive routine immunizations. Emergency vaccination campaigns are being planned to contain the spread.
 
 
 
 With measles now confirmed in all 6 regions, officials warn that the outbreak could worsen without swift intervention and support from local and international health partners.
 
 
 
 The outbreak comes as the region continues to battle multiple infectious disease threats. On World Polio Day last October [2024], the Federal Ministry of Health in Mogadishu, backed by WHO and UNICEF, urged intensified vaccination campaigns to fight what remains the world's longest-running outbreak of variant poliovirus type 2. Health Minister Dr. Ali Haji Adam warned that unless immunization efforts were expanded, diseases like measles, cholera, and polio could overwhelm Somalia's already stretched health infrastructure, especially in drought-affected or flooded regions where vaccine access is limited.

Title: PERTUSSIS - POLAND: INCREASE IN CASES
summary: Poland is experiencing a significant surge in whooping cough cases, with a substantial increase in reported infections compared to the previous year. Experts are concerned that the situation may worsen. Contributing factors include low vaccination rates among adults, as immunity wanes over time, and migration.

Whooping cough outbreak in Poland: number of infected people has increased 35 times in a year
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Poland has recorded a record increase in whooping cough cases. The number of cases in 2024 was more than 30 thousand, which is 35 times more than in the previous year [2023]. Such figures are cited by Polish media, citing data from the National Institute of Public Health. 

Experts warn that the problem could worsen. In the first 2 months of 2025 alone, 5000 new cases have already been recorded. There are at least 2 reasons that may contribute to the increase in the incidence of pertussis.

The first is the low level of pertussis vaccinations among adults, despite the fact that immunity expires every 8-10 years. In Poland, vaccination of children is mandatory, and there is little awareness of the need for regular vaccination for adults. This affects the decrease in the general immunity of the population, which is of concern, especially in the context of pathogen mutation.

Migration has become an additional risk factor for the development of whooping cough. Other factors also contributed to the increase in the incidence of pertussis.

Title: HEPATITIS A - UKRAINE: (KYIV)
summary: An outbreak of hepatitis A has occurred in Kyiv, leading to the implementation of distance learning for schoolchildren in the affected district. The source of the outbreak is currently under investigation. While there is no specific treatment, vaccination is available for prevention. The investigation includes testing and sampling to determine the cause and spread of the disease.

Date: Fri 16 May 2025
 
 Source: UNN [edited]
 
 <https://unn.ua/en/news/hepatitis-a-outbreak-in-kyiv-more-than-30-children-are-ill-the-source-of-infection-has-not-yet-been-established>
 
 
 
 
 
 Hepatitis A outbreak in Kyiv: more than 30 children are ill, the source of infection has not yet been established
 
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 In the capital's Vidradny microdistrict, an outbreak of viral hepatitis A has been recorded -- 65 people have fallen ill, including 31 children. Due to the incident, all schoolchildren in the district have been transferred to distance learning. The cause of the outbreak is still being investigated. This was announced during a briefing by Natalia Gunchenko, Deputy Director General of the Kyiv City Center for Disease Control and Prevention, reports UNN.
 
 
 
 According to the specialist, there is no specific treatment for this disease. The only thing for prevention is a vaccine against viral hepatitis A. It is not included in the calendar of mandatory vaccinations. It is included in the recommended vaccinations. The population can buy the vaccine at their own expense and vaccinate both adults and children. As of 10 May 2025, 330 people have been vaccinated at their own expense. Most of them are children, fewer adults said the medic.
 
 
 
 Gunchenko noted that viral hepatitis affects all age groups of the population, but most often children and young people under the age of 35 are at risk. Older people are more likely to have already "had" the disease and, accordingly, have immunity to it. The investigation into the sources of the outbreak in the capital is still ongoing.
 
 
 
 Given that the disease has a fairly long incubation period (almost up to 50 days), experts have to conduct a retrospective study of the outbreak: take water samples from reservoirs, drinking fountains and centralized water supply. In addition, many people, especially children and adolescents, are being tested for the disease.
 
 
 
 Earlier, UNN wrote that 34 cases of hepatitis A were recorded in Kyiv, 20 of which were in children. The causes of the outbreak are being investigated, experts are conducting epidemiological investigation and taking anti-epidemic measures.

2nd hepatitis A death reported in a family within 2 days in Kollam
--------------------------------
A 15-year-old girl succumbed to hepatitis A on Sunday [18 May 2025] while receiving treatment at the Thiruvananthapuram Govt Medical College Hospital, 2 days after her elder sister also died of the disease. Ontario reports 182 new measles cases, surpassing 1600 since outbreak began
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Health officials say measles has infected 182 more people in Ontario over the last week, bringing the province's case count to 622 since an outbreak began in October [2024]. Public Health Ontario's measles report says there have been 119 hospitalizations, including 9 intensive care cases. Of those hospitalized, 95 percent were unvaccinated, including 89 children.

This is the third consecutive week Ontario is reporting that new cases are in the 200-range, which is on the higher end since experts started keeping track of weekly spread.

Southwestern Public Health Unit's Dr. Ninh Tran called the province's case count over the last few weeks "significant." His public health unit is still where most of the new cases are concentrated. However, he says most cases are no longer infectious.

"This week has been the highest week, and it is being driven by really good detection and significant transmissions in households," Tran says.

Southwestern [Ontario] has had 104 new cases reported locally over the past week, he says, which is higher than the province's data because of differences in reporting periods.

Measles cases in Alberta have reached nearly 400 since mid-March [2025], infecting just over 120 kids under age 5. The highly contagious disease continues to primarily infect unvaccinated children, infants, and teenagers, both in Ontario and Alberta.

[Byline: Hannah Alberga]

Southern Alberta sees spike in measles cases
----------------------------------
The number of patients suffering from measles grew by 29 cases in southern Alberta Friday [16 May 2025], a daily increase greater than what the entire USA recorded in a week. The rise brings the total number of reported cases in Alberta to 438, most of which are concentrated in southern Alberta, where almost 300 people have come down with the disease. The region is followed by the Central Zone with 91 confirmed cases. Edmonton and Calgary have reported 6 and 11 cases, respectively.

The figure has made Alberta the province with the second-highest number of cases in the country, behind Ontario, where the number of people with the disease exceeded 1600 as of Friday [16 May 2025].

The CDC reported 20 new cases in the US between 4 and 11 May, and another 2 cases between 11 and 15 May [2025].

The rate of measles in Alberta is highest among children aged under 5 to 17. More than 350 people suffering from the disease belong to the cohort. Children under 5 are most at risk of serious complications, particularly babies who are aged 6 to 12 months, said Dr. James Talbot, public health physician and the province's former chief medical officer of health, in an interview last week.

During a panel hosted by the Alberta Medical Association on 8 May [2025], he urged Albertan families to move quickly on getting themselves and their children vaccinated, citing 3 reasons. The first, he said, is that measles is widely known to be a highly contagious virus that spreads quickly. Secondly, he explained that because it often takes time for measles symptoms to show up, there are probably more cases of the infection in Alberta than those reported.

"And thirdly, the percentage of kids unimmunized or partially immunized is very high in Alberta," he said.

The panel followed days after a provincial update on 5 May [2025], wherein Adriana LaGrange, the province's health minister, and Dr. Sunil Sookram, Alberta's interim chairperson confirmed that actions are being taken to expand the provincial response to the outbreak.

The most recent update arrives as measles makes a comeback in Canada, especially in Alberta, where immunization rates are among the lowest in the country. Provincial data shows that only 71.6 percent of 7-year-olds were fully vaccinated against measles in 2024.

In the south zone, where the majority of the cases are concentrated, multiple communities show vaccination rates well below 50 percent in 2024, including the County of Forty Mile (30.2 percent), Lethbridge (46.7 percent), and the Municipality of Taber (39.1 percent).

In the central zone, Two Hills Country reports a paltry vaccination rate of 24 percent. Out of 350 confirmed cases on 10 May [2025], 318 weren't vaccinated.

The low vaccination rates have been ascribed to vaccine hesitancy, anti-vaxxer sentiment, and a false sense of security from past infrequent exposure to the virus.

[Byline: Hiren Mansukhani]

Montreal Public Health reports a case of measles
-------------------------------------------
A person in the midst of a contagious measles outbreak reportedly stayed in Montreal from 4 to 7 May [2025] and visited several places in the city, according to the Montreal Regional Public Health Department (DRSP). According to the notice issued Friday [16 May 2025] by the DRSP, the person visited 4 businesses, a hotel, and a private residence for seniors (RPA) during their stay in Montreal.

They reportedly stayed at the Quality Inn Dorval and visited the Ch√¢teau Pierrefonds residential care home. The list of places frequented by the person infected with measles also includes Boulangerie Non Solo Pane, Tacos Frida, Bar Messorem, and the Subway restaurant on Saint-Charles Boulevard in Kirkland.

The DRSP therefore urges anyone who has been exposed to measles to check whether they are adequately protected against measles. It reiterates that vaccination remains the best way to protect against this virus. Public Health also emphasizes that measles is an extremely contagious disease and that the risk of catching measles is 9 out of 10 if an unprotected person comes into contact with a sick person.

Quebec has faced 2 measles outbreaks, the last of which ended in April 2025. A senior medical advisor with the Public Health Agency of Canada says the country could lose its measles-eradication status if the highly contagious disease continues to spread in the fall.

Dr. Marina Salvadori warned of this possibility 2 weeks ago, as Ontario's case count rose by nearly 200 infections, adding that it would only happen if the prolonged spread continued beyond mid-October 2025. Even if the eradication status ends, she believes measles can be eliminated again in the country.

Measles eradication is the absence of continuous transmission of the disease for 12 months or more in a given geographic area. Canada achieved this status in 1998.

[Byline: Quentin Dufranne]

summary: Health officials in Faryab province are concerned about a rise in measles cases among children. Source: Pajhwok Afghan News [edited]

Rising measles cases in children worries Faryab officials
----------------------------------------------
Health officials in northern Faryab province have expressed concern over an increasing number of measles cases in children and are urging families not to neglect vaccinating their children against the disease. Dr. Arash Agha, head of the pediatric department at the 100-bed hospital in Maimana, told Pajhwok Afghan News that measles remained common in Faryab not only this year but also last year [2024].

More than 40 children with measles are admitted to the pediatric ward daily, which is above the capacity of the ward, and most patients may be referred to other health centers, private hospitals, and neighboring provinces, he added. He attributed the reason behind the increasing measles cases to poor coverage of routine vaccination, lack of awareness and people's lack of referral to health centers, irresponsibility of vaccinators who do not cover their respective areas, and delays in implementing the nationwide campaign.

Measles is a type of respiratory infection and its symptoms include fever, cough, runny nose, and skin problems in various parts of the body. Despite the availability of a vaccine, it is still one of the causes of death worldwide. Dr. Agha urged families to pay serious attention to administering measles vaccine to their children.

Dr. Mohammad Ibrahim Karimi, chief physician at the provincial hospital, explained the hospital had a capacity of 100 beds and more than 140 children were admitted to the pediatric ward daily, most of them measles patients. Most of the severe measles patients are from remote districts and Ghormach district of western Badghis province, where there are no health facilities, he added.

Maulvi Khan Agha Asad, acting director of Public Health Department, confirms that the number of measles cases and deaths in the province have increased compared to previous years. In the past, a general campaign was launched every 5 years, but since 2022, no general campaign has been carried out, and most children born between 2022 and 2025 have not been vaccinated. The lack of awareness among people about the importance of vaccination, the distance of health centers from villages, the lack of transportation, and the aversion of some families towards vaccination are factors contributing to the increase in measles cases. The acting director asked families to vaccinate their children against this dangerous disease.

[H], a resident of Khwaja Sabzposh district, explained her grandson contracted measles almost 3 weeks ago. He is in critical condition and hospitalized in Maimana Hospital, but doctors have recommended he should be transferred to better-equipped hospitals outside the province for treatment.

[Byline: Qutbuddin Kohi]
