Mexico City expands vaccination efforts amid measles outbreak
-------------------------------------------------------------

Mexico's Ministry of Health has set up a phone service to direct residents of Mexico City to vaccination sites, as the capital joins the list of regions affected by the country's ongoing measles outbreak. The measure was announced after local authorities confirmed 4 infections and reported more than 350 suspected cases in the city.

The toll nationwide has now reached over 4300 cases across 21 states, with Chihuahua at the center of the crisis. That state alone accounts for nearly all of the country's fatalities -- 14 of 15 -- and over 90% of confirmed patients, reports El País. While other regions such as Oaxaca have reported smaller clusters, the slow but steady appearance of new cases has kept health authorities on alert.

In a press release, the ministry is urging the public to call 079 to identify the nearest vaccination unit. The service is free, and immunization is available at all public health centers. Officials stressed that doses are sufficient to meet demand, part of an effort to avoid the shortages that have frustrated patients and doctors in recent years.

The vaccination drive is directed at children as young as 6 months, adolescents, and adults up to 49 years old who lack a full immunization record, as well as teachers, health workers, and people considered at greater risk of complications. Families are being asked to review children's records and complete pending schedules, particularly for children under 5 years old. If documentation is missing, health staff will provide new cards or vaccination certificates.

Specialists had anticipated that measles could reach Mexico City given its size and mobility levels. Mauricio Rodríguez, an epidemiologist, says that vaccination rates in large cities tend to be higher than in rural areas, which may limit transmission. He adds that the capital experienced a prison-related outbreak in 2020 that was followed by a significant immunization campaign, potentially leaving the population better prepared today.

To reinforce supplies, the federal government announced in June [2025] the purchase of nearly 27 million doses, with the majority aimed at adults and 3.5 million set aside for young children. Still, the country faces a vaccination gap. The WHO reported that over 340 000 children in Mexico missed all routine immunizations in 2024, a delay that cannot be resolved quickly.

The focus remains on Chihuahua, where the outbreak first emerged among seasonal workers in Mennonite farming communities. Authorities expanded eligibility beyond the standard age range to include adults up to 49 years old, responding to the risk faced by this mobile workforce. The PAHO estimated earlier this year [2025] that about 1.8 million people in the state required an additional dose to contain the spread.

Although the pace of infections has slowed compared to the first months of the year, continued reporting of isolated cases across states keeps the risk of resurgence alive. Experts warn that if sustained transmission continues, Mexico and the region could lose their measles-free certification, a designation granted in 2024. To preserve that status, the outbreak must be brought under control before it completes a year of continuous spread.

[Byline: Aura Moreno]

Title: HEPATITIS A - CUBA (05): (GUANTANAMO) MILITARY RECRUITS
summary: A hepatitis outbreak is affecting a military unit in Cuba, primarily impacting newly recruited soldiers. The outbreak highlights poor sanitary conditions and inadequate management of the health crisis. The Ministry of Public Health has acknowledged a slight increase in hepatitis A cases nationwide and has issued recommendations for preventing the spread of the disease.
full text:
Date: Sun 31 Aug 2025
Source: Cuba Headlines [edited]
<https://www.cubaheadlines.com/articles/309999#google_vignette>


Hepatitis Outbreak Hits Military Unit at Guantanamo Border Brigade
------------------------------------------------------------------
An outbreak of hepatitis is impacting the Guantanamo Border Brigade, specifically within the Eastern Battalion, where most soldiers are newly recruited teenagers. Reports reveal the severity of the situation that military authorities are attempting to conceal.

According to independent journalist Yosmany Mayeta Labrada, who shared details on his Facebook page, families of the young recruits are seeking information about their children's health. However, they only receive evasive and reassuring messages from military leadership, while the disease continues to spread unchecked.

Communications from the recruits themselves contradict the official narrative, indicating that the outbreak is proliferating within the unit without effective measures to curb the spread. This incident highlights the weak sanitary conditions in military units and the lack of transparency in managing emergencies that endanger dozens of adolescents sent for mandatory service.

The absence of official information exacerbates the families' anxiety as their children fall ill within facilities shrouded in secrecy. The regime refuses to publicly acknowledge the outbreak.

On 27 Aug 2025, the Ministry of Public Health (Minsap) confirmed a "slight increase" in hepatitis A cases nationwide. Hepatitis A is an acute viral disease affecting the liver, primarily transmitted through ingestion of contaminated water or food. Its spread is facilitated by poor hygiene practices and inadequate water supply and treatment.

Francisco Durán, national director of Hygiene and Epidemiology at Minsap, advised, "Whenever possible, boil water and use chlorine tablets, which are occasionally available at pharmacies in our country, to treat the water before consuming it. Additionally, ensure that vegetables are thoroughly washed with chlorinated water."

[Byline: Bella Nunez]

Title: POLIOMYELITIS - PAPUA NEW GUINEA (03): FIRST HUMAN CASE IN ONGOING OUTBREAK
summary: Papua New Guinea has confirmed its first human case of polio in an ongoing outbreak. To combat the spread, the country launched a nationwide immunization campaign targeting children with a specific vaccine. A second round of the campaign is planned, including a different type of vaccine. The country is also working to improve routine immunization, strengthen surveillance systems, and enhance sample collection. The World Health Organization and partners are supporting these efforts through digital tools and community engagement. The goal is to interrupt transmission and protect children from the disease.
full text:
Date: Thu 28 Aug 2025
Source: World Health Organization (WHO) [edited]
<https://www.who.int/papuanewguinea/news/detail/28-08-2025-papua-new-guinea-confirms-first-human-case-of-polio-in-ongoing-outbreak>


Papua New Guinea confirms first human case of polio in ongoing outbreak
----------------
The National Department of Health (NDoH), in collaboration with the World Health Organization (WHO) and partners, has confirmed the first human case of paralytic poliomyelitis (cVDPV2) in Papua New Guinea. The case involves a 4-year-old unvaccinated boy from Lae, Morobe Province, who developed acute flaccid paralysis.

This marks a pivotal moment in the country's polio response, confirming that the virus has transitioned from environmental detection to direct impact on children.

To combat the spread, Papua New Guinea launched a nationwide supplementary immunization activity (SIA) on 11 Aug 2025, targeting children under 10 years with the novel oral polio vaccine (nOPV2). The campaign has been extended to 5 Sep [2025] to help provinces reach the critical 95% coverage target. As of 26 Aug [2025], national coverage stands at 41.2%, with Hela Province leading at 91%.

A second round of SIA is scheduled from 29 Sep to 17 Oct [2025], which will include both nOPV2 and inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) to provide stronger and longer-lasting protection. Over 9 million doses of nOPV2 and 4 million doses of IPV have been secured, along with additional stocks of measles-rubella, pentavalent vaccines, vitamin A, and deworming tablets.

Routine immunization is being integrated into both SIA rounds, especially for children under 2 years. Through the periodic intensification of routine immunization (PIRI), provinces are encouraged to boost coverage and build long-term community resilience. While uptake varies across regions, targeted efforts are underway to strengthen budget utilization and enhance service delivery, ensuring broader protection for children.

WHO and partners are leveraging digital tools like mSupply and ODK to track vaccine stocks and accountability. Community engagement is also a priority, with outreach through churches, schools, youth groups, and local leaders to ensure no child is left behind.

To date, 122 cases of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) have been reported, with 93 tested and confirmed negative for cVDPV2 -- an important indicator of active surveillance. Efforts are being intensified to strengthen surveillance systems nationwide, with targeted support for provinces that have yet to report cases.

The National Department of Health, with support from WHO and partners, is working to improve stool sample adequacy -- currently at 62.5% -- through enhanced training, logistics, and active case finding. These measures are vital to ensuring timely detection and response, and to interrupting poliovirus transmission across all communities.

"Polio is preventable. The vaccines are safe, effective, and free," said Dr. Sevil Huseynova, WHO Representative in PNG. "But we must act together -- with urgency and unity. WHO stands ready to support every province, every health worker, and every community."

Papua New Guinea's fight against polio continues with unwavering determination and robust collaboration across all levels of society. With strong leadership, active community engagement, and steadfast international support, the country is working to interrupt transmission and protect every child -- moving closer to ending polio in PNG once and for all.

Title: MEASLES - USA (116): (WISCONSIN, OHIO, TEXAS)
summary: Measles outbreaks have been identified in multiple locations. One outbreak is ongoing in Wisconsin, with local spread occurring. Another cluster of cases has been identified in Ohio within a single family. Additionally, an adult case of measles has been confirmed in Texas, which was travel-related. Health officials are working to identify and follow up on potential exposures and contacts in all affected areas. Public health guidance emphasizes the importance of vaccination and seeking medical care if symptoms are present.

Date: Tue 2 Sep 2025
Source: CIDRAP [edited]
<https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/measles/wisconsin-measles-outbreak-grows-ohio-reports-family-cluster>


Wisconsin measles outbreak grows as Ohio reports family cluster
---------------------------------------------------------------
In Wisconsin, health officials in Oconto County have confirmed 9 more measles cases, raising the state's outbreak total to 23. The outbreak in Oconto County, located in northeastern Wisconsin, began in early August 2025. The Wisconsin Department of Health Services (WDHS) said in a 29 Aug 2025 update that 2 people have been hospitalized. 

"The ongoing investigation indicates that measles is spreading locally. At this time, the investigation has not identified locations in public settings for which a full list of exposed people cannot be obtained," the WDHS said. The state's measles dashboard reflects that all 23 of the confirmed case-patients are unvaccinated. The most affected group is children ages 5 to 17 years old (13 cases), followed by adults (7 cases). 

Elsewhere, the Zanesville-Muskingum County Health Department in Ohio on 30 Aug 2025 announced that it has identified 3 confirmed measles cases in children, all unvaccinated, the agency said in a Facebook post. All 3 are from the same family and are currently at home and are improving. Muskingum County, home to Zanesville, is located in east central Ohio.

Health officials said they are working with the family and hospital to identify and follow up on any exposures and contacts.

[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]

[2] Texas (Rains County)
Date: Tue 2 Sep 2025
Source: CBS19 [edited]
<https://www.cbs19.tv/article/news/local/measles-in-east-texas/501-cfbc5d51-2a3b-4c41-b597-af48fb7c3ac3>


NET Health confirms adult case of measles in East Texas
-------------------------------------------------------
A case of adult measles has been confirmed in Rains County, according to the Northeast Texas Public Health District (NET Health).

A spokesperson for NET Health said they received confirmation of a travel-related positive case in an adult resident living in Rains County. The patient voluntarily self-isolated at their residence while contagious and has since recovered. 

Persons who have been fully vaccinated against measles with 2 doses of the MMR vaccine have a very low risk of contracting the disease," NET Health said in a statement released Tuesday [2 Sep 2025]. "However, unvaccinated individuals remain at higher risk, as do those in some other groups..."

Those groups include the following demographics:
- Children too young to have received both doses of the MMR vaccine yet
- Anyone who have received only one dose of MMR
- Those with compromised immune systems

"Measles is a highly contagious viral illness that spreads when an infectious person coughs or sneezes," the statement said. "Someone with measles can spread it to susceptible people for up to 4 days prior to the appearance of a rash and for up to 4 days after rash onset."

Symptoms of measles can include a high fever, coughing and runny nose, white spots inside the mouth (koplik spots) and an appearance of a rash 3-5 days after symptoms begin. In some cases, measles can also cause illness leading to hospitalization or death.

NET Health advises East Texans to follow these steps to help prevent measles:
- If you believe you have spent time with someone who has measles and you are experiencing symptoms consistent with measles, please seek medical care as soon as possible. It is important to call your healthcare provider ahead of time so they can take steps to keep you from exposing other patients.
- Persons who have not been vaccinated or are unsure of their vaccination status are encouraged to contact their healthcare provider about receiving the MMR vaccine.
- Vaccination prior to exposure provides protection and can modify the course of disease.

[Byline: Jude Ratcliff]

Measles weekly monitoring report, week 34 (August 17-23, 2025)
--------------------------------------------------------------

Current measles situation
In 2025, a total of 4799 measles cases (4452 confirmed, 347 probable) have been reported by 10 jurisdictions (Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Northwest Territories, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, Quebec, Saskatchewan), as of August 23, 2025.

In week 34 (August 17-23, 2025), 82 new measles cases (64 confirmed, 18 probable) were reported by 6 jurisdictions (Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Ontario).

There are a total of 575 recent measles cases (553 confirmed, 22 probable), reported by 29 health units within 7 jurisdictions (Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Saskatchewan), as of August 23, 2025.

There has been one death reported by Ontario in a congenital case of measles who was born pre-term and had other underlying medical conditions.
